subject: Re: How do I make Unit Testing practical?
msgSnippet: ... There are alternatives to embedded code (if you mean what I think you mean, using inner classes to test). ... I felt the same way a while back, about XP
messageBody:
--- Scott Palmer <scott.palmer@...>
wrote:
> environment, but if my application is to be
> downloaded and there are
> megabytes of embedded test code it can become an
> issue. (So far my
> code is a small fraction of the download, so this
> isn't an issue - yet)

There are alternatives to "embedded" code (if you mean
what I think you mean, using inner classes to test).

> Another comment:
> I've been trying to get started with the unit
> testing and have been
> encouraging other's in my company to try it too, but
> I can't get any
> buy-in. I'm finding it difficult to get started so I
> don't really have
> a convincing argument for it other than "I've read
> that it is a great
> thing" :), obviously if I can make it work for me it
> would help. It's
> good to hear that others have had the same issues
> and have gotten past
> them. The examples make it look so simple and
> easy...

I felt the same way a while back, about XP in general
and unit testing specifically. I gave up trying to
convince others by talk. At that point it WAS just
something good I'd heard about.

Now, nearly a year later I actually practice (as much
as is possible) TDD and unit test first. Now it is
not just something good I've read about, but I can
tell my coworkers of actual benefit that comes from
it.

One concrete case is with some installation code that
me and several other members of our team have written.
I've found ways to refactor the code to be nearly
100% unit tested and now the test cycles take about 3
seconds whenever there is a change instead of a couple
of hours (time spent actually installing the OS,
manually hitting buttons, testing upgrade paths, etc,
etc). My coworkers who have been through the pain of
doing it the other way see the wisdom of unit testing
when I show them the time and effort saved.

I guess I'm saying that once you have been doing it
for a while, you will know how to inform them of the
benefits in ways that actually will make sense to them
and that you can back up with cold, hard, data. But
first you need to get "test-infected" yourself, and
that requires a bit of discipline and time trying
things out. (it doesn't take long though, since the
benefits are very very real).

- Jeff Tulley
